channel.title: Italiano con Geoff
channel.description: Recent content on Italiano con Geoff

item.title: Italian Alphabet
item.description:
Italian Alphabet #

The Italian alphabet has 21 letters. Here’s a breakdown with pronunciation examples and notes:

Letter Pronunciation Example Notes
A as in amore Love
B as in bello Beautiful
C as in cane (dog) or ciao (hello) Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
D as in donna Woman
E as in elefante Elephant
F as in fatto Done
G as in gatto (cat) or gioco (game) Hard before A, O, U; soft before E, I
H Silent in Italian Used in hotel, etc.
I as in isola Island
L as in luna Moon
M as in mare Sea
N as in notte Night
O as in orologio Clock
P as in pane Bread
Q as in quadro Painting
R as in rosso Red, rolled
S as in sole Sun
T as in tavolo Table
U as in uva Grapes
V as in vino Wine
Z as in zebra Can sound like ’ts’ or ‘dz’

Foreign Letters #

Letters like J, K, W, X, Y appear in borrowed words (e.g., jeans, kiwi).

item.title: Lesson 1.1: Basic Greetings
item.description:
Lesson 1.1: Basic Greetings â€“ Say Hello Like an Italian ðŸ‘‹ #

Welcome to your first lesson, where you’ll learn how to greet people like a true Italian. By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll master ciao, buongiorno, and moreâ€”all under the patient guidance of Viktor, your Ukrainian-Italian neighbor. Whether heâ€™s sharing tips over morning espresso or helping you decode Italian hand gestures, Viktor is here to make sure Geoff survives (and thrives) in Italy.

item.title: Lesson 5.1: Shopping Essentials â€“ Key Phrases and Scenarios
item.description:
Lesson 5.1: Shopping Essentials â€“ Key Phrases and Scenarios ðŸ›ï¸ #

Shopping in Italy can feel like an adventure, a performance, and a challenge all rolled into one. But donâ€™t worryâ€”this lesson has everything you need to conquer markets, boutiques, and souvenir shops without accidentally ordering 3 kilos of tomatoes instead of a leather belt.

Key Phrases Youâ€™ll Master #

1. Asking the Price #

  • Quanto costa? (How much does it cost?)
    • The essential phrase youâ€™ll use everywhere, from the market to high-end stores.
  • Quanto costano? (How much do they cost?)
    • Plural version for when youâ€™re eyeing multiple itemsâ€”like shoes. Lots of shoes.

2. Polite Requests #

  • Posso provarlo/la? (Can I try it on?)
    • For clothing. Use lo for masculine items (e.g., il cappotto, the coat) and la for feminine items (e.g., la giacca, the jacket).
  • Posso vedere quello? (Can I see that?)
    • Perfect for pointing at something just out of reach, like the prettiest scarf in the shop.

3. Handling Money #

  • Posso pagare con carta di credito? (Can I pay with a credit card?)
    • Always good to ask, especially in small shops where cash is often king.
  • Ha il resto? (Do you have change?)
    • Because handing over a â‚¬50 bill for a â‚¬4 purchase might earn you a raised eyebrow.

4. Numbers in Action #

Brush up on your Italian numbers to avoid confusion:

item.title: Exercise 5.1: Shopping Essentials Practice
item.description:
Exercise 5.1: Shopping Essentials Practice ðŸ›ï¸ #

Ready to put your Italian shopping skills to work? This exercise will test your ability to ask for prices, make polite requests, and navigate common shopping situations without accidentally purchasing 10 kilos of potatoes when you only wanted two.

1. Fill in the Blanks â€“ Shopping Scenarios #

Complete the sentences with the correct Italian word or phrase.

  1. You: Scusi, _____ costa questa borsa? (Excuse me, how much does this bag cost?)
  2. You: Posso _____ quella giacca? (Can I try on that jacket?)
  3. Vendor: Costa trenta euro.
    You: _____ pagarla con carta di credito? (Can I pay for it with a credit card?)
Answers

Answers: #

  1. Quanto
  2. provarla
  3. Posso

2. Match the Phrase â€“ What Does It Mean? #

Match the Italian shopping phrase to its correct meaning in English.

item.title: Lesson 2.1: Introducing Yourself
item.description:
Lesson 2.1: Introducing Yourself â€“ Making a Great First Impression #

Benvenuto! Now that you know how to greet people in Italian, letâ€™s take the next step: introducing yourself! Italians are known for their warmth and friendliness, and knowing how to introduce yourself is essential for making connections. In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to say your name, ask for someone elseâ€™s, and share a bit about where youâ€™re from. Ready? Andiamo! (Letâ€™s go!)

item.title: Lesson 3.1: Ordering Coffee Like a Local
item.description:
Lesson 3.1: Ordering Coffee Like a Local â˜• #

Welcome to the world of Italian cafÃ©s, where coffee is life, and the barista is the unspoken king or queen of the counter. In this lesson, weâ€™ll teach you how to confidently order your coffee, avoid rookie mistakes, and blend in with the locals (or at least try). Just remember, Italians take their coffee seriously, so bring your A-game.

The Golden Rule: Start with a Greeting #

Before you even think about uttering your coffee order, greet the barista. Italians are all about politeness, and skipping this step is a one-way ticket to awkward-ville.

item.title: Lesson 4.1: Asking for Directions
item.description:
Lesson 4.1: Asking for Directions â€“ Navigating Like a Pro ðŸ—ºï¸ #

Picture this: Youâ€™re wandering the winding streets of Rome, desperately searching for the Colosseum. You check your phone, but your GPS insists youâ€™re in the middle of the Tiber River. Fear not! With this lesson, youâ€™ll learn how to ask for directions, decode Italian responses, and even charm the locals along the way.

Key Phrases Youâ€™ll Master #

  • Dovâ€™Ã¨…? â€“ “Where is…?” (The essential starter for your lost-in-Italy survival kit.)
  • Come si arriva a…? â€“ “How do I get to…?” (Because pointing at your map can only get you so far.)
  • A sinistra / A destra â€“ “To the left / To the right” (Yes, itâ€™s time to master cardinal directions â€“ or at least fake it convincingly.)
  • Sempre dritto â€“ “Straight ahead” (The response that often leads to more questions.)

The Reality of Italian Directions #

Hereâ€™s the thing: Italians rarely give directions without a bit of drama. Expect plenty of hand gestures, rapid-fire explanations, and the occasional shrug of uncertainty. But hey, even if you donâ€™t understand a word, youâ€™ll look cool nodding and smiling.

item.title: Exercise 1.1: Basic Greetings Practice
item.description:
Exercise 1.1: Basic Greetings Practice #

Welcome to your first exercise! Itâ€™s time to put those Italian greetings to the test. Donâ€™t worry if you get some wrong â€“ remember, even Italians sometimes mix up their greetings after an extra espresso! â˜• So, letâ€™s dive in and have some fun.

1. Multiple Choice â€“ What Would You Say? #

Choose the correct Italian greeting for each scenario.

  1. You bump into a friend at 9 AM, and they look like theyâ€™re still half asleep. What do you say?

item.title: Exercise 2.1: Introducing Yourself Practice
item.description:
Exercise 2.1: Introducing Yourself Practice #

Ready to practice introducing yourself? This exercise will help you reinforce the phrases you learned in Lesson 2. Remember, even if you make a mistake, Italians love enthusiasm, so keep trying!

1. Fill in the Blanks â€“ Complete the Conversation #

Use the correct Italian phrases to complete each sentence.

  1. You: Ciao! _____ (My name is) Giovanni.
  2. You: _____ (Whatâ€™s your name?)
  3. New Friend: Mi chiamo Sofia. _____ (Nice to meet you!), Giovanni!
  4. You: _____ (The pleasure is mine!), Sofia! _____ (Iâ€™m from) Firenze.
Answers

Answers: #

  1. Mi chiamo
  2. Come ti chiami?
  3. Piacere!
  4. Il piacere Ã¨ mio! Sono di

2. Multiple Choice â€“ Choose the Right Response #

Pick the correct response for each situation.

item.title: Exercise 4.1: Asking for Directions Practice

1. Fill in the Blanks â€“ Finish the Phrase #

Complete each sentence with the correct Italian word or phrase.

  1. You: Scusi, come si arriva a _____? (Fill in the blank to ask how to get to the train station.)
  2. You: Dovâ€™Ã¨ il _____? (Fill in the blank to ask for the public restroom.)
  3. You: Grazie mille! And the local responds: _____ (How do they politely say, “You’re welcome”?)
Answers

  1. la stazione
  2. bagno pubblico

2. Match the Directions â€“ Where Should You Go? #

item.title: Lesson 4.2: Understanding Directions
item.description:
Lesson 4.2: Understanding Directions â€“ Mastering the Italian Rapid-Fire Response ðŸ—£ï¸ #

Youâ€™ve asked for directionsâ€”great start! But now comes the real challenge: deciphering the rapid-fire response that sounds like an Italian opera performed at 2x speed. Donâ€™t worry; by the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll decode those directions and make it to your destination without accidentally ending up in someoneâ€™s backyard.

What Youâ€™ll Learn #

  • Common Directional Terms: Words like lÃ¬ (there), laggiÃ¹ (down there), and subito dopo (right after) will no longer leave you scratching your head.
  • How to Slow Down the Locals: Polite phrases to ask them to repeat (or breathe).
  • Gestures: The Secret Decoder Ring: Italian hand gestures often tell you more than the words.
  • When in Doubt, Smile and Nod: Learn to fake understanding until you figure it out.

The Reality of Rapid Italian Directions #

Hereâ€™s the deal: Italians donâ€™t just give directionsâ€”they paint verbal masterpieces. Youâ€™ll get landmarks, historical context, and maybe a recommendation for the best pizza nearby. Itâ€™s delightful, but also overwhelming. The trick? Focus on key words, follow the gestures, and be ready for a little adventure.

item.title: Lesson 5.2: Market Magic â€“ Navigating Italian Markets
item.description:
Lesson 5.2: Market Magic â€“ Navigating Italian Markets ðŸ¥•ðŸ… #

Ah, Italian marketsâ€”a whirlwind of vibrant colors, enticing smells, and vendors shouting prices faster than you can say gelato. But donâ€™t worry! By the end of this lesson, youâ€™ll know how to shop like a seasoned local, even if your Italian vocabulary is limited to â€œpastaâ€ and â€œciao.â€

What Youâ€™ll Learn #

  • Key Market Phrases: From asking for prices to negotiating deals, weâ€™ve got you covered.
  • Etiquette 101: The doâ€™s and donâ€™ts of Italian markets, including why touching the tomatoes might earn you a scolding.
  • Survival Tips: Learn how to navigate the chaos, understand rapid-fire Italian, and walk away with your dignity (and your change).

Essential Phrases for the Market #

  1. Quanto costa? (How much does it cost?)

item.title: Understanding 'Ne' in Italian
item.description:
Understanding “Ne” in Italian â€“ Your Secret Weapon for Sounding Like a Local ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹ #

“Ne” is like the Swiss Army knife of Italian grammarâ€”it looks small and simple, but it does a lot. It means â€œof itâ€ or â€œof themâ€ and helps avoid repetition when you’re talking about quantities. Italians love efficiency, especially when it comes to words (and making coffee).

But whoâ€™s here to help you master it? None other than Viktor, the friendly Ukrainian vendor who works at your favorite Italian market. Letâ€™s dive in!

item.title: Lesson 1.2: Saying Goodbye Like a Pro
item.description:
Lesson 1.2: Saying Goodbye Like a Pro ðŸ‘‹ #

Welcome back, language adventurer! Now that youâ€™ve mastered saying hello, itâ€™s time to tackle the other half of every great conversation: saying goodbye. Italians have a knack for turning even farewells into an art form, so letâ€™s dive into the many ways you can gracefully exit any situation (or linger dramaticallyâ€”your choice).

The Many Flavors of â€œGoodbyeâ€ #

In Italy, how you say goodbye depends on the time of day, your relationship, and whether or not you plan to see the person again. No pressure! Here are your main options:

item.title: Lesson 2.2: Talking About Your Hobbies and Interests
item.description:
Lesson 2.2: Talking About Your Hobbies and Interests ðŸŽ¸ðŸŽ¨ #

Welcome back! In this lesson, weâ€™ll dive into talking about hobbies, interests, and even jobs in Italian. Whether youâ€™re into painting, skydiving, or just binge-watching your favorite shows, Italians will be delighted to hear about it (especially if you throw in a smile). Letâ€™s get started!

Mastering Piacere: The Magic Word #

The Italian verb piacere is your best friend for expressing what you like. But be warnedâ€”itâ€™s a little tricky because it works backwards! Instead of saying â€œI like pizza,â€ youâ€™re literally saying, â€œPizza is pleasing to me.â€ (Italians take their pizza very seriously.)

item.title: Lesson 3.2: Navigating the CafÃ© Scene Like a Pro
item.description:

So, youâ€™ve learned how to order your cappuccino without fear of judgment. But an Italian cafÃ© is more than just a place for caffeineâ€”itâ€™s a battlefield of etiquette, speed, and style. In this lesson, youâ€™ll master the unspoken rules of the Italian cafÃ© and learn how to blend in like a local. Letâ€™s caffeinate and conquer!

Step 1: Know Your Vocabulary #

The key to a successful cafÃ© visit is knowing what you want and how to say it. Hereâ€™s your cheat sheet:

item.title: Lesson 5.3: Boutique Basics â€“ Polishing Your Shopping Skills
item.description:
Lesson 5.3: Boutique Basics â€“ Polishing Your Shopping Skills ðŸ‘—ðŸ‘  #

Shopping in Italian boutiques is like stepping onto a fashion runwayâ€”youâ€™re surrounded by elegance, luxury, and sometimes prices that require a deep breath. In this lesson, youâ€™ll learn to navigate these stylish spaces with confidence, charm, and just the right amount of Che bello!.

What Youâ€™ll Learn #

  • Polished Phrases: Ask for sizes, colors, and styles like a pro.
  • Etiquette 101: Master boutique etiquette and avoid the dreaded â€œWho let this tourist in?â€ glare.
  • Cultural Insights: Understand the unique Italian approach to high-end shopping.
  • Confidence Boosters: Learn how to try on clothes gracefully (and how to politely decline without offending anyone).

Essential Phrases for Boutique Shopping #

  1. Posso vedere quella borsa? (Can I see that bag?)

item.title: Irregular verbs
item.description:
Irregular verbs #

Verbi irregolari #

1. Essere (to be) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sono sono stato/a sarÃ²
tu sei sei stato/a sarai
lui/lei Ã¨ Ã¨ stato/a sarÃ 
noi siamo siamo stati/e saremo
voi siete siete stati/e sarete
loro sono sono stati/e saranno
  • Present: Sono feliceâ€¦ finchÃ© non controllo il saldo del mio conto. â€“ I am happyâ€¦ until I check my bank balance.
  • Past: Ero al lavoro, ma la mia mente era in vacanza. â€“ I was at work, but my mind was on vacation.
  • Future: SarÃ² in formaâ€¦ forseâ€¦ un giorno! â€“ I will be in shapeâ€¦ maybeâ€¦ one day!

2. Avere (to have) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io ho ho avuto avrÃ²
tu hai hai avuto avrai
lui/lei ha ha avuto avrÃ 
noi abbiamo abbiamo avuto avremo
voi avete avete avuto avrete
loro hanno hanno avuto avranno
  • Present: Ho fame ogni due ore come se fossi in allenamento per una maratona culinaria. â€“ Iâ€™m hungry every two hours, like Iâ€™m training for a food marathon.
  • Past: Ho avuto unâ€™idea brillanteâ€¦ peccato che fosse alle 3 di notte e ora non la ricordo piÃ¹. â€“ I had a brilliant ideaâ€¦ too bad it was at 3 a.m. and now I canâ€™t remember it.
  • Future: AvrÃ² un milione di euro… appena trovo una lampada magica. â€“ Iâ€™ll have a million euros… as soon as I find a magic lamp.

3. Andare (to go) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vado sono andato/a andrÃ²
tu vai sei andato/a andrai
lui/lei va Ã¨ andato/a andrÃ 
noi andiamo siamo andati/e andremo
voi andate siete andati/e andrete
loro vanno sono andati/e andranno
  • Present: Vado in palestraâ€¦ per fare finta di allenarmi e scattare qualche selfie. â€“ Iâ€™m going to the gymâ€¦ to pretend to work out and take a few selfies.
  • Past: Sono andato al supermercatoâ€¦ e ho dimenticato quello che dovevo comprare. â€“ I went to the storeâ€¦ and forgot what I needed to buy.
  • Future: AndrÃ² a correreâ€¦ appena smette di piovere (forse tra un mese). â€“ Iâ€™ll go for a runâ€¦ as soon as it stops raining (maybe in a month).

4. Fare (to do/make) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io faccio ho fatto farÃ²
tu fai hai fatto farai
lui/lei fa ha fatto farÃ 
noi facciamo abbiamo fatto faremo
voi fate avete fatto farete
loro fanno hanno fatto faranno
  • Present: Faccio la lista delle cose da fare, poi faccio finta di non averla mai scritta. â€“ I make a to-do list, then pretend I never wrote it.
  • Past: Ho fatto una torta… che Ã¨ uscita dal forno come un mattoncino. â€“ I made a cake… that came out of the oven like a brick.
  • Future: FarÃ² del mio meglioâ€¦ o almeno ci penserÃ² seriamente. â€“ I will do my bestâ€¦ or at least Iâ€™ll think about it seriously.

5. Dare (to give) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io do ho dato darÃ²
tu dai hai dato darai
lui/lei dÃ  ha dato darÃ 
noi diamo abbiamo dato daremo
voi date avete dato darete
loro danno hanno dato daranno
  • Present: Do consigli come se fossi un guru, ma non li seguo mai io stesso. â€“ I give advice like a guru, but I never follow it myself.
  • Past: Ti ho dato lâ€™ultima fetta di pizza… ma solo perchÃ© ne avevo giÃ  mangiate quattro. â€“ I gave you the last slice of pizza… but only because Iâ€™d already had four.
  • Future: DarÃ² una mano con il trasloco… appena il mio mal di schiena sparisce. â€“ Iâ€™ll help with the moveâ€¦ as soon as my back pain disappears.

6. Stare (to stay/be) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io sto sono stato/a starÃ²
tu stai sei stato/a starai
lui/lei sta Ã¨ stato/a starÃ 
noi stiamo siamo stati/e staremo
voi state siete stati/e starete
loro stanno sono stati/e staranno
  • Present: Sto bene, grazieâ€¦ anche se sto cercando disperatamente il caffÃ¨. â€“ Iâ€™m well, thanksâ€¦ though Iâ€™m desperately searching for coffee.
  • Past: Siamo stati in spiaggia… e ci siamo abbronzati come gamberi. â€“ We stayed at the beach… and got sunburned like lobsters.
  • Future: StarÃ² calmoâ€¦ ma solo se nessuno tocca il mio dessert. â€“ Iâ€™ll stay calmâ€¦ but only if no one touches my dessert.

7. Venire (to come) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io vengo sono venuto/a verrÃ²
tu vieni sei venuto/a verrai
lui/lei viene Ã¨ venuto/a verrÃ 
noi veniamo siamo venuti/e verremo
voi venite siete venuti/e verrete
loro vengono sono venuti/e verranno
  • Present: Vieni alla festa? C’Ã¨ pizza gratis! â€“ Are you coming to the party? Thereâ€™s free pizza!
  • Past: Sono venuto alla tua riunioneâ€¦ e ho dormito per metÃ  del tempo. â€“ I came to your meetingâ€¦ and slept through half of it.
  • Future: VerrÃ² a trovartiâ€¦ non appena finisco questa maratona su Netflix. â€“ Iâ€™ll come visit youâ€¦ as soon as I finish this Netflix marathon.

8. Dire (to say/tell) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io dico ho detto dirÃ²
tu dici hai detto dirai
lui/lei dice ha detto dirÃ 
noi diciamo abbiamo detto diremo
voi dite avete detto direte
loro dicono hanno detto diranno
  • Present: Dico sempre â€œdomani inizio la dietaâ€â€¦ ma domani non arriva mai. â€“ I always say â€œIâ€™ll start the diet tomorrowâ€â€¦ but tomorrow never comes.
  • Past: Mi hai detto che sarebbe stato facile… non so se ridere o piangere. â€“ You told me it would be easyâ€¦ I donâ€™t know whether to laugh or cry.
  • Future: Ti dirÃ² un segretoâ€¦ appena lo scoprirÃ² anchâ€™io. â€“ Iâ€™ll tell you a secretâ€¦ as soon as I figure it out myself.

9. Sapere (to know) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io so ho saputo saprÃ²
tu sai hai saputo saprai
lui/lei sa ha saputo saprÃ 
noi sappiamo abbiamo saputo sapremo
voi sapete avete saputo saprete
loro sanno hanno saputo sapranno
  • Present: So tuttoâ€¦ soprattutto quando si tratta di serie TV. â€“ I know everythingâ€¦ especially when itâ€™s about TV series.
  • Past: Non ho saputo rispondereâ€¦ ma ho annuito come se capissi tutto. â€“ I didnâ€™t know the answerâ€¦ but I nodded as if I understood everything.
  • Future: SaprÃ² cosa fareâ€¦ appena Google me lo dirÃ . â€“ Iâ€™ll know what to doâ€¦ as soon as Google tells me.

10. Uscire (to go out) #

Pronoun Present Past (Passato Prossimo) Future
io esco sono uscito/a uscirÃ²
tu esci sei uscito/a uscirai
lui/lei esce Ã¨ uscito/a uscirÃ 
noi usciamo siamo usciti/e usciremo
voi uscite siete usciti/e uscirete
loro escono sono usciti/e usciranno
  • Present: Usciamo stasera? O rimaniamo a casa a guardare serie? â€“ Are we going out tonight? Or staying home to binge-watch series?

Why Do We Use ‘ho’ and ‘sono’ in the Past Tense? #

Learning Italian grammar can feel like cooking pasta al dente: a bit of pressure, but worth it! If youâ€™re wondering why Italians switch between “ho” and “sono” in the past tense, letâ€™s dive in (without overcooking it).
